It originates from the epithelial cells of the thymus and may present with mass effect symptoms, such as compression of the superior vena cava (SVC), leading to SVC syndrome, which explains distended neck veins. The CECT thorax typically shows a well-defined anterior mediastinal mass, which can have solid and cystic components, and may enhance with contrast. Given the correlation between MG and thymoma, this diagnosis must be considered strongly when such a clinical-radiological picture is seen.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Lipoma – Incorrect. Lipomas are benign fatty tumors that may appear in the mediastinum but are rare and not associated with MG. They also do not commonly cause compression symptoms such as SVC syndrome.
  • • C. Carcinoma lung – Incorrect. While lung cancer can cause SVC syndrome, it is typically located in the right upper lobe or central lung areas and does not have a known association with MG. The combination of MG and an anterior mediastinal mass strongly favors thymoma over lung cancer.
  • • D. Cardiomegaly – Incorrect. Cardiomegaly is enlargement of the heart, usually seen on a chest X-ray or imaging as an enlarged cardiac silhouette. It is not associated with MG and is unlikely to cause distended neck veins unless it leads to congestive heart failure, which would present differently and would not explain a discrete mediastinal mass on CECT.

questions.text: A young patient presented with recurrent colicky abdominal pain. On examination RBC was present along with following finding in urine examination? What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Glomerulonephritis – Incorrect. While glomerulonephritis can also present with RBCs in urine, it typically leads to dysmorphic RBCs, proteinuria, and sometimes red cell casts, not recurrent colicky abdominal pain. It is a glomerular pathology, not associated with stone formation or colic.
  • • C. Oxalate stone – Incorrect. Oxalate stones (calcium oxalate) are more radiopaque and commonly occur due to dietary or metabolic causes, but they are not exclusive to young patients and do not show characteristic hexagonal crystals. Their urine crystals are envelope-shaped, not hexagonal.
  • • D. Polycystic kidney disease – Incorrect. While autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) can cause abdominal or flank pain and hematuria, it usually presents with palpable kidneys, hypertension, and family history. Urinalysis would not show cystine crystals, and recurrent colicky pain is less typical than dull pain due to enlarged kidneys or cyst rupture.

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Erosions – Incorrect. Erosions refer to superficial breaks in the mucosal lining and appear as shallow, red or inflamed areas on endoscopy. They are generally seen in esophagitis due to reflux or infection. They do not form raised or tubular structures and lack the bluish, vascular appearance seen in varices.
  • • C. Barrett's – Incorrect. Barrett's esophagus is characterized by metaplastic columnar epithelium replacing the normal squamous lining due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). On endoscopy, Barrett’s appears as salmon-pink or velvety red mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction, but it does not produce raised vascular structures like varices.

questions.text: Complication of TPN in sepsis patient in ICU
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Hyperlipidaemia – Incorrect. While TPN can include lipid emulsions, hyperlipidaemia is not the most immediate or common complication, particularly in the acute setting. It can occur with prolonged lipid infusion or in patients with lipid metabolism disorders, but it is less frequent than hyperglycaemia.
  • • C. Hypoglycaemia – Incorrect. Hypoglycaemia may occur if TPN is suddenly discontinued or not tapered properly, but this is uncommon and typically preventable with proper management. In contrast, overfeeding with glucose is more commonly associated with hyperglycaemia.
  • • D. Hypertriglyceridemia – Incorrect. Although it can be a complication of TPN, especially with high lipid content or in patients with underlying metabolic disorders, hypertriglyceridemia is less common and less acutely problematic than hyperglycaemia, especially in septic patients.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with recurrent diarrhoea, abdominal pain and foul smelling stools. Colonoscopic image given. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis) – Incorrect. FAP is a genetic condition characterized by hundreds to thousands of colonic adenomatous polyps, usually without pseudomembranes. It typically presents with bleeding, change in bowel habits, or asymptomatic screening, not recurrent foul-smelling diarrhea.
  • • C. UC (Ulcerative Colitis) – Incorrect. Ulcerative colitis presents with bloody diarrhea, urgency, and tenesmus. Colonoscopy in UC shows diffuse continuous mucosal inflammation, ulceration, and loss of vascular pattern, not pseudomembranes. The symptoms and colonoscopic findings differ from those in pseudomembranous colitis.
  • • D. Acute gastritis – Incorrect. Acute gastritis affects the stomach, not the colon, and does not cause pseudomembranes. It typically presents with epigastric pain, nausea, and sometimes vomiting, and would not produce the described colonoscopic findings.

questions.text: 12 year old boy with acute pain in left scrotal region. Dx?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Testicular appendage with torsion – Incorrect. While this can also cause acute scrotal pain, it is typically less severe, and patients may be afebrile with localized tenderness at the upper pole of the testis. A “blue dot sign” might be visible through the scrotal skin. Blood flow to the testis remains normal on Doppler, unlike in testicular torsion.
  • • C. Testicular cyst – Incorrect. Testicular cysts are usually painless and incidental findings on imaging. They do not present acutely and would not cause signs of ischemia or gangrene.
  • • D. Hematoma – Incorrect. A scrotal hematoma may result from trauma and presents with pain and swelling, but there is often a clear history of injury. Hematoma alone would not cause ischemia unless associated with vascular compromise, which is rare.

questions.text: A patient presented with Solitary thyroid nodule with features of thyrotoxicosis. next investigation?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. USG – Incorrect. Ultrasound is important in the characterization of thyroid nodules, such as determining whether they are solid or cystic, assessing for suspicious features, and guiding FNAC. However, it does not assess thyroid function. In a case with overt signs of thyrotoxicosis, biochemical assessment (T3, T4, TSH) takes precedence before imaging.
  • • C. Thyroid scan – Incorrect. A thyroid scan (radioisotope scan using Tc-99m or I-123) is used after confirming low TSH to determine if the nodule is "hot" (functioning) or "cold" (non-functioning). However, it is not the first step—thyroid function tests are needed first to determine the need for the scan.
  • • D. FNAC – Incorrect. Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is useful in evaluating the risk of malignancy in a thyroid nodule. However, in a hyperfunctioning nodule, FNAC is not recommended initially, as toxic nodules are rarely malignant. Therefore, FNAC is usually considered after functional status is clarified.

questions.text: Elderly male, 3 weeks H/O trauma. Image given?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. EDH (Epidural Hematoma) – Incorrect. Epidural hematomas are usually caused by arterial bleeding, often from the middle meningeal artery, and are classically associated with lucid intervals followed by rapid deterioration. On imaging, they appear as a biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense lesion and do not cross suture lines. EDH is more common in younger individuals with acute trauma, not consistent with a 3-week delayed presentation.
  • • C. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage) – Incorrect. Subarachnoid hemorrhage involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space and typically presents acutely with sudden, severe headache ("thunderclap headache"), neck stiffness, and possible loss of consciousness. It is usually caused by a ruptured aneurysm or severe trauma. Imaging shows blood in the basal cisterns or sulci, not a crescentic collection.
  • • D. Contusion – Incorrect. Brain contusions are focal areas of hemorrhage and edema within the brain parenchyma, usually seen on imaging as ill-defined hyperdense areas often in the frontal or temporal lobes. They are associated with parenchymal injury, not subdural collections, and typically present acutely, not with a delayed onset weeks after trauma.

questions.text: A 50-years-old male presented in the emergency with high BP (160/100) and heart rate of 120/min. A CECT is done which is given below. What is the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Low molecular weight heparin – Incorrect. Low molecular weight heparin is commonly used in managing deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism, or other conditions requiring anticoagulation. However, in the case of aortic dissection, anticoagulation therapy is contraindicated due to the risk of exacerbating bleeding and worsening the dissection. Instead, medications such as beta-blockers are used to control blood pressure and heart rate to reduce the stress on the aorta.
  • • C. Beta blocker medication – Incorrect. While beta blockers are crucial in the initial management of aortic dissection to reduce heart rate and blood pressure, they are not sufficient as the only treatment. Surgical repair is needed in cases involving the ascending aorta. Beta blockers help in reducing the force of cardiac contraction, thus lowering the pressure on the aortic wall, but they are not a definitive treatment on their own.
  • • D. Vitamin K inhibitors – Incorrect. Vitamin K inhibitors (such as warfarin) are used for chronic anticoagulation in conditions like atrial fibrillation, deep vein thrombosis, or in patients with mechanical heart valves. These are not used in the acute setting of an aortic dissection. In fact, anticoagulation therapy can increase the risk of catastrophic bleeding in patients with aortic dissection, making it contraindicated in this case.

questions.text: Patient present with constant chest pain and following radiological finding. Initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Beta blockers are essential in reducing heart rate, myocardial oxygen demand, and blood pressure, thereby preventing further ischemic damage to the heart.
  • • Vasodilators (such as nitroglycerin) are used to relieve angina by dilating coronary arteries and improving blood flow to the myocardium, thereby reducing chest pain.
  • • Together, beta blockers and vasodilators work synergistically to reduce the workload on the heart and alleviate chest pain in cases of ACS or unstable angina.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Surgical management – Incorrect. While surgical interventions (such as angioplasty, stenting, or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)) may be needed in certain cases of severe coronary artery disease or MI, they are typically not the initial treatment for chest pain in a patient with unstable angina or ACS. Surgical management is considered after further diagnostics and if more invasive intervention is required, but the first step is usually medical management with beta blockers and vasodilators to stabilize the patient.
  • • B. Vasodilator – Incorrect. While vasodilators are effective in alleviating chest pain by improving blood flow, beta blockers are also crucial in controlling heart rate and blood pressure in patients with unstable angina or ACS. Just using vasodilators alone may not adequately control the hemodynamic aspects of the patient's condition. Thus, they should be used in combination with beta blockers to achieve optimal results.
  • • C. Beta blockers – Incorrect. Although beta blockers are critical in controlling heart rate and reducing myocardial oxygen demand, they are typically used in combination with vasodilators for initial management of chest pain in ACS or unstable angina. Using beta blockers alone may help manage heart rate and blood pressure, but it does not provide the full therapeutic effect in relieving chest pain due to ischemia, which is why vasodilators are also required.

questions.text: Patient with acute urinary retention, with SPC done. RGU showing along stricture. Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In cases where strictures are resistant to other treatments or when they are located in areas that are difficult to reach, this approach provides the best functional and anatomical outcomes, including the restoration of the urinary flow and avoidance of recurrence.
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Metal catheter – Incorrect. A metal catheter would not address the underlying issue of the urethral stricture itself. It might provide temporary drainage in cases of acute retention, but it does not resolve the stricture causing the obstruction. It is usually used as a short-term solution, while definitive treatment such as urethrotomy or grafting is required to restore normal urinary function.
  • • B. Dilatation – Incorrect. Dilatation is often used in cases of shorter, less severe strictures and can provide temporary relief. However, it is not as effective for long, complex strictures or when the stricture is located in an area where dilatation would cause more harm than good. Recurrent strictures can form after dilatation, which is why it is typically not the first choice for more severe cases, and long-term solutions such as urethrotomy or grafting are preferred.
  • • C. Endoscopic Urethrotomy – Incorrect. Endoscopic urethrotomy is often used for short strictures or in situations where the stricture can be cut through via a scope. While this procedure can be effective in certain cases, it is less successful in cases of longer strictures or strictures that involve a large portion of the urethra. The success rate is lower in complex strictures, and recurrence is common, making it less ideal than buccal grafting for long-term outcomes.

questions.text: Bladder stone with H/O proteus infection?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • A. Oxalate – Incorrect. Oxalate stones form in acidic urine, typically in the absence of infection. They are often associated with conditions like hypercalciuria, gastrointestinal disorders, or dietary factors, but they do not form as a result of urease-producing infections like Proteus. While oxalate stones can cause bladder issues, they are not typically associated with Proteus infections, and they tend to form in a lower pH environment, which is opposite to the alkaline urine environment created by urease-producing bacteria.
  • • C. Uric acid – Incorrect. Uric acid stones form in acidic urine and are often associated with gout, hyperuricemia, or conditions with high cell turnover, such as leukemia. These stones are not typically linked with Proteus infections or the alkaline urine environment created by urease-producing bacteria. Uric acid stones usually form in the absence of infection and are less likely to be associated with urease-producing bacteria like Proteus, which is more likely to cause phosphate (struvite) stones.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about this image?
questions.correct_answer: A. Esophagus is the correct site
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • B. Most common in adults – Incorrect. While foreign body ingestion can occur in both children and adults, it is more common in children because they tend to put objects in their mouths more frequently. In adults, foreign body ingestion is usually related to dentures, swallowing difficulty, or alcohol intoxication. Adults may also be at higher risk due to conditions such as dysphagia or neurological impairments that affect swallowing.
  • • C. Mostly above cricoid – Incorrect. Foreign bodies in the esophagus tend to get stuck in areas with narrower luminal diameters, such as the upper esophageal sphincter (at the cricopharyngeus), at the aortic arch, and the lower esophageal sphincter (near the diaphragm), not necessarily just above the cricoid. While impaction above the cricoid may occur, foreign bodies can get lodged at any of the narrowing points along the esophagus, not exclusively above the cricoid.
  • • D. Mediastinal infection not present – Incorrect. Mediastinal infection can occur as a complication if there is a perforation in the esophagus due to foreign body impaction. In such cases, air and bacteria can leak into the mediastinum, leading to mediastinitis, which is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition. If the image shows a foreign body or structural issue in the esophagus, mediastinal infection could be a concern if there is perforation or if the issue leads to further complications.
